abstract.p: Seth D Bykofsky letter on September 17 article questions why budget surplus in Town of Hempstead is not being used to benefit townspeople (S)

block.p: Re the efforts of the Town of Hempstead's Republican leadership to insulate itself from voter anger over Nassau County's fiscal crisis [''G.O.P. Fights for Bastion of Its Power: Hempstead,'' Sept. 17]: the sister ship of the Titanic must not think itself unsinkable.

Re the efforts of the Town of Hempstead's Republican leadership to insulate itself from voter anger over Nassau County's fiscal crisis [''G.O.P. Fights for Bastion of Its Power: Hempstead,'' Sept. 17]: the sister ship of the Titanic must not think itself unsinkable.

The county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, is adrift in a deficit sea, while his political sibling, the town supervisor, Richard J. Guardino, has a $50 million budget surplus. But what plans are there to use this cache for the benefit of our townspeople? The beaches and the parks are lovely, but have those entrenched at Town Hall looked to the squalor of our hamlets and villages? One hundred years of haphazard development, bereft of planning, have scarred our township. Quality of life is slowly and perhaps irretrievably slipping away.
The county has nothing. The town does little more. The former squanders money; the latter, opportunity. Not really so different after all, are they?
